awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Bulk synthesis of stishovite near ambient pressure and temperature
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: The project targets synthesis of stishovite, a form of SiO2 (silica) and one of the hardest materials known to mankind at hydrothermal conditions. Presently, this precious form of silica can only be attained at extremely high pressure (ca. 100,000 times atmospheric pressure) in a technically very difficult and expensive process that yields only small quantities. The new approach of this project mimics geological conditions, and grows the crystals from aqueous solutions in bulk quantities. The process occurs close to ambient pressure and temperature conditions, and consequently, will be inexpensive and scalable. This facilitates new applications of stishovite as an abrasive, in cutting tools, and as a hard ceramic material in other applications. 

TECHNICAL DETAILS: Stishovite, a polymorph of silica (SiO2), is - together with cubic boron nitride - only second in hardness to diamond. Moreover, among the hardest materials known it is the only oxide, thus naturally resistant against degradation through oxidation. Despite these outstanding properties, stishovite is not used as an engineering material, because it can be synthesized only at pressures above 8 GPa. Although technically feasible, the high-pressure route is not scalable and rather expensive. In this project, a kinetically controlled hydrothermal synthesis approach for stishovite is being developed. The process occurs near ambient pressure and temperature conditions and is similar to the industrial production of quartz crystals. The difference to industrial quartz growth is that instead of quartz seed crystals, stishovite seed crystals are employed. The temperature gradient in the autoclave system allows for the supersaturation of the silicate solution in the growth chamber and the kinetically controlled growth of the stishovite seed crystals from the supersaturated solution. The experiments are guided by computations that explore and predict optimal synthesis conditions. The research is a seminal approach to synthesize high pressure phases near ambient conditions from solution which suggests a transformational impact on the synthesis of high-pressure phases. The project is training graduate students in high-pressure and hydrothermal synthesis techniques and computational materials chemistry. The results from the research are part of the graduate level course "Solid State Chemistry".

por.por_cntn:
We describe two major outcomes of our research: the first addresses whether hydrothermal synthesis of stishovite SiO2 is feasible. The second outcome is the unexpected discovery that a new polymorph of TiO2 is attainable by moderate tensile stresses.

Stishovite, a high-pressure polymorph of SiO2, is the hardest oxide material. Its synthesis usually requires several thousand atmospheres of pressures, and the tiny amounts attained even from "large-volume" presses prevent its commercial use. Providing a new directive to receive large amounts of stishovite near ambient pressure, we proposed a scalable hydrothermal synthesis for stishovite, similar to industrial manufacturing of quartz SiO2. A fundamental element of the proposed hydrothermal process is the use of nano-sized stishovite seed crystals attained through conventional high-pressure synthesis. To initiate the growth of larger stishovite crystals, those seed crystals must remain stable in the aqueous medium under hydrothermal conditions, which also involves temperatures of several hundred degrees. 

Since this new synthesis strategy for stishovite was untested and exploratory, we used computational methods to investigate stability of stishovite seed crystals. Using acurate quantum-chemical calculations we explored the hydroxylated surfaces of stishovite, as they will be encountered on seed crystals used in hydrothermal processing. Furthermore, we investigated different pathways for hard crystalline stishovite and for its surfaces to deteriorate through transformation into the much softer and, thus, undesirable cristobalite SiO2 and computed energy profiles and barriers along those paths.

Our results indicate that stishovite surfaces are energetically severely disadvantaged against surfaces of other silica polymorphs. Moreover, nano-crystalline stishovite seed crystals exhibit -- due to their size and relative high proportion of surfaces -- a reduced kinetic barrier against transformation into cristobalite SiO2. Consequently, our results provide two major arguments, namely 

  • surfaces of stishovite are energetically unfavorable, and 
  • there is a low activation energy for the deterioration of nano-crystalline stishovite into cristobalite, 

that speak against our initial hypothesis. 

The first argument indicates major difficulties to retain or establish a well-ordered stishovite-type surface during growth. The second argument indicates that seed crystals or their surfaces may transform into cristobalite-type arrangements already at typical processing temperatures.

Our conjecture is not an immediate disprove of our initial hypothesis, since we could not account for a variety of side effects that come along in hydrothermal processing. Among these may be highly particular alkaline concentrations and other specific controlled conditions. However, the two arguments contribute to the uphill battle hydrothermal synthesis of an (only) meta-stable compound such as stishovite SiO2 will face.

While studying transformation mechanisms between silicon dioxide polymorphs, stishovite SiO2 and cristobalite SiO2, we explored -- computationally -- the same processes for titanium dioxide TiO2 as well. The analogous structure to stishovite is rutile-TiO2, which is the most common natural form of TiO2 and the typical white pigment used in paints, plastics, and paper. Rutile has also generated much interest as a functional oxide for applications in photo-catalysis, especially for CO2 reduction. A cristobalite-type analog of TiO2, however, does not occur in nature and has never been synthesized.

We used computational methods to investigate the transformation from rutile-TiO2, to cristobalite-TiO2. Through quantum-chemical calculations we accessed transition pressures as well as the energy profile for a direct pathway between the two configurations of TiO2. 

Our results show that cristobalite-TiO2 can be attained at surprisingly small negative pressures. Such negative pressures are realized by tensile stresses, and the required magnitudes correspond to tensile stresses typical for thin film deposition. Moreover, we compute the activation barrier for the conversion of rutile-TiO2 to cristobalite-TiO2 to be low enough that appreciable kinetics will happen at moderate temperatures. Consequently, we propose that a new polymorph of titania, cristobalite-type TiO2, can be attained by first depositing rutile-type TiO2 on strained curved substrates (e.g. concave wafer), and then relaxing the substrate to induce high tensile stresses in the deposited films. Tensile stresses (negative pressures) will transform rutile-TiO2 to cristobalite TiO2, and the temperature needed to activate the process falls into the range available in standard processing equipment.

While this approach will fabricate only thin films of cristobalite-TiO2, it provides access to a previously unknown compound.

Modified by: Peter Kroll
